page.title: 09BRADLEY POND BOVEY TRACEY
page.content: {Bradley Ponds}are three disused clay pits.{The Devon Nature Trust}own the ponds. The reserve is also the most south westerly place you can find a nightingale. There are a variety of flowers in the reserve such as: wild orchids, pink campion, buttercups, spearwort, ragged robin, birdsfoot, trefoil, dog roses, self- heel, foxgloves, michelmas daisy, st john's wort ,water iris, pink pursley, mares tail a reed like plant and dandelions. At the old clay pit, the silver birch is very dominant and the oak does not grow so well. Bradley Pond is 10 acres 2 of which are the lake. There were ducks and evidence of rabbits and birds. There were 2 birds nests of which 1 was half-built. It is the habitat for damson and dragonflies. All the trees were deciduous. There were many tadpoles and baby frogs.
